Art title 1: We Are Their Theology (by Anthony Gurrola)
Artist Statement 1:
(By Anthony Gurrola) It's hard to ignore the image of God when I see it in my children everyday.

It's even harder to comprehend it, when my children look like me.

We can get so down on ourselves for falling short.

Mostly because our shortcomings are reflected through our little ones.

When we get frustrated, they get frustrated.

When we act out in anger, so do they.

When we say something we shouldn't, they pick it up.

But in all the sort comings,

The greater of these things is love.

And I'll tell you what.

Love sticks better than a broken attitude.

When we love, they are free.

When we are patient, they learn kindness.

When we are gentle, they learn forgiveness.

When we are selfless, they learn sacrifice.

And when we show them Jesus,

It shapes their entire world.

May they know how much Yahweh loves them, because they see how much Dad loves mom.

May they see how much Yahweh cares for them, because we don't ignore the little things.

May they see how much Yahweh fights for them, because we take the time to correct them.

May they see how much Yahweh goes before them, because we planned a fun day of adventure.

May they see how much Yahweh looks out for them, because they feel safe in the arms of dad.

May they see that Yahweh is home,
Because He was invited to the house everyday.

And may I see how much Yahweh loves me, every moment that I love them.

As I see more of myself in them everyday,
May they see more of Jesus in me.

And while no parent has it all figured out,

May the pursuit of my children and
God's pursuit of me be enough for perfect theology.
Story Title again:
BLOG:
Why We Say All Sins Are Equal in God's Sight
excerpt:
I think that as regards salvation, the reason that before God all sins are equal is because it's not about the consequences; it's about the choosing to disobey.


Whether we steal a matchbox car or a real car in both cases we have chosen to disobey. I'm pretty sure God's kingdom isn't about toys or Teslas. It's about having a heart to obey.


The good thing is I think God is always ready for us if we repent. But what about those things I continually hold onto despite being told "let go."



Ugggh. I'm thinking of those things in my life. The things I don't let go of because I think their impact is so inconsequential. But doesn't that show I am an animal that acts on the rewards and consequences of this world instead of God's instructions?


What if it were that very smallest thing that proves to myself and God that I am not of a heart to obey? Out of all the great temptations in this world, I would not even give up that small thing.


God, help me have a heart to obey. Please help us obey.


Raw Spoon, 10-26-17
Research 4-link:

American Standard Version
7 A good name is better than precious oil; and the day of death, than the day of one's birth. 2 It is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting
